skill.name: Command Development
skill.description: This skill should be used when the user asks to "create a slash command", "add a command", "write a custom command", "define command arguments", "use command frontmatter", "organize commands", "create command with file references", "interactive command", "use AskUserQuestion in command", or needs guidance on slash command structure, YAML frontmatter fields, dynamic arguments, bash execution in commands, user interaction patterns, or command development best practices for Claude Code.
skill.summary: This skill should be used when the user asks to "create a slash command", "add a command", "write a ...
skill.author: anthropics

security_audit.summary: This skill is pure documentation containing markdown examples of Claude Code slash command patterns. All static findings are false positives triggered by documentation examples. The skill teaches safe command development including allowed-tools restrictions and proper bash execution syntax. No executable code, network access, or credential handling exists.

content.value_statement: Users need guidance on creating reusable slash commands for common workflows. This skill provides comprehensive documentation on command structure, YAML frontmatter options, dynamic arguments, bash execution patterns, and best practices for developing Claude Code commands.
actual_capabilities: Create slash commands with Markdown file format
Configure commands using YAML frontmatter fields
Execute bash commands safely with !`command` syntax
Organize commands with namespacing and subdirectories
limitations: Provides documentation only, does not execute commands on user behalf
Does not create actual command files (users must write them)
Does not modify existing commands or project files
Focused on Claude Code command syntax, not general scripting

use_cases.title: Build Plugin Commands
use_cases.description: Create plugin-specific commands with ${CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT} references and multi-script workflows for distribution.

use_cases.title: Standardize Team Workflows
use_cases.description: Define shared commands in .claude/commands/ for consistent code review, testing, and deployment workflows.

use_cases.title: Personal Productivity
use_cases.description: Create personal commands in ~/.claude/commands/ for cross-project utilities and frequently-used prompts.

prompt_templates.title: Create Simple Command
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants a basic review command
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a simple slash command that reviews code for quality issues. Show me the markdown file format with description and allowed-tools fields.

prompt_templates.title: Add Arguments
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I create a command that accepts arguments? Show me how to use $ARGUMENTS and positional arguments like $1, $2 in command prompts.

prompt_templates.title: Bash Execution
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to run shell commands
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to execute bash commands inside a slash command. Include examples of git commands, npm scripts, and how to restrict tools with allowed-tools.

prompt_templates.title: Plugin Commands
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a plugin command that uses ${CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT} to reference plugin scripts. Include multi-script workflow pattern with error handling.

output_examples.input: Create a deploy command that takes environment and version as arguments
output: Deploy application to $1 environment using version $2
Expands to: Deploy application to staging environment using version v1.2.3

best_practices: Use clear verb-noun naming (review-code, deploy-app) and keep descriptions under 60 characters for clean /help display
Always specify allowed-tools with most restrictive permissions needed (e.g., Bash(git:*), not Bash(*))
Document arguments with argument-hint and provide usage examples in comments for other developers
anti_patterns: Avoid writing commands as messages to users instead of instructions to Claude (commands must tell Claude what to do)
Do not use overly broad allowed-tools like Bash(*) when specific commands like Bash(git:*) would suffice
Avoid creating commands that do too many things; prefer single-responsibility commands that do one thing well

faq.question: Where should I store my commands?
faq.answer: Project commands go in .claude/commands/ (shared with team), personal commands in ~/.claude/commands/ (available everywhere), plugin commands in plugin-name/commands/.

faq.question: How do I restrict what tools a command can use?
faq.answer: Use the allowed-tools frontmatter field. Examples: allowed-tools: Read, Bash(git:*), allowed-tools: Bash(npm:*)

faq.question: Can commands execute bash scripts?
faq.answer: Yes, use !`command` syntax inside command prompts. Always restrict Bash access in allowed-tools for security.

faq.question: How do I pass arguments to a command?
faq.answer: Use $ARGUMENTS for all args as string, or $1, $2, $3 for positional args. Document with argument-hint field.

faq.question: What is YAML frontmatter?
faq.answer: Optional metadata at start of command files between --- markers. Includes description, allowed-tools, model, argument-hint, and disable-model-invocation fields.

faq.question: How do I reference files in a command?
faq.answer: Use @path/to/file syntax. Claude will read the file contents before processing. Works with relative and absolute paths.
